FLORIMEL.</br>Is Daphne the pride of the plain,</br>Content to be Florimel's spouse?</br>Can she listen with love to his strain?</br>Is she charm'd with the villager's vows?</br>The kidlings that browze on the rock,</br>And the fleeces that bathe in the rill,</br>Nay, the all of my pastoral flock,</br>Believe me, is her's, if she will.

DAPHNE.</br>Good shepherd, be artless and wise?</br>Can ambition with meekness agree?</br>Contentment's the charter I prize,</br>No wealth has a virtue for me.</br>'Tis enough to be Florimel's wife,</br>And duties domestic fulfil;</br>I am sure I can love your for life,</br>So I thank you, I think that I will.

FLORIMEL.</br>The miser his plumb may possess,</br>The statesman his title and star,</br>Our cares and our crimes will be less,</br>And sha'nt we be happier far?</br>From fortune we'll brave each rebuff,</br>Your smiles can adversity kill;</br>Your heart will be treasure enough,</br>And I'll keep it, dear Daphne, I will.

DAPHNE.</br>My candour coquets may despise,</br>And prudes may my passion condemn:</br>But innocence scorns a disguise,</br>And I hope I'm as modest as them;</br>And, I think, if there's faith in the brook,</br>I'm as fair as the maid of the Mill;</br>So Florimel give me your crook,</br>For in sooth I'm determin'd I will.</br>
